sections.title: The Source and Value of Counsel

verses.text: Every friend says, 'I am your friend,' but some friends are truly only so in name.
verses.comment: Sirach warns that not all who call themselves friends are trustworthy. True friendship is tested in adversity.

verses.text: Is it not a sorrow to the heart when a companion turns into an enemy?
verses.comment: The pain of betrayal is echoed in the Psalms and ultimately in the betrayal of Christ by Judas.

verses.text: O evil inclination! From what were you created, to cover the earth with deceit?
verses.comment: This verse points toward the universal struggle with sin, which originated with the fall of Adam and Eve.

verses.text: A companion rejoices with a friend in good times, but in trouble, he will turn against him.
verses.comment: True friendship is revealed in adversity.

verses.text: A friend will stay with a friend in prosperity, and in adversity, he will turn into an enemy.
verses.comment: The reliability of friends is tested in hardship, a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: Do not forget a friend during the battle, and do not be unmindful of him when you distribute your spoils.
verses.comment: Loyalty to friends in conflict and prosperity is emphasized; sharing spoils references ancient Near Eastern customs of dividing booty after victory (cf. 1 Samuel 30:24), underscoring fidelity and generosity as virtues.

verses.text: All counselors praise the counsel they give, but some give counsel in their own interest.
verses.comment: Sirach warns that advisers often promote their own interests, cautioning discernment when listening to counsel (cf. Proverbs 12:5); self-interest can cloud good advice.

verses.text: Be wary of a counselor, and learn first what is his interest, for he will take thought for himself. He may cast the lot against you
verses.comment: Discernment of a counselor's motives is key, for personal bias may lead to misleading guidance—a common wisdom principle echoed in Proverbs 14:15.

verses.text: and tell you, “Your way is good,” and then stand aside to see what happens to you.
verses.comment: A hypocritical counselor may outwardly affirm your plans yet abandon you to the consequences, highlighting the need for trustworthy advisers (cf. Psalm 1:1).

verses.text: Do not consult the one who regards you with suspicion; hide your intentions from those who are jealous of you.
verses.comment: Consulting those with ill intent, envy, or suspicion is unwise, as their advice is likely tainted; Proverbs 27:4 speaks to the dangers of jealousy.

verses.text: Do not consult with a woman about her rival or with a coward about war, with a merchant about business or with a buyer about selling, with a miser about generosity or with the merciless about kindness, with an idler about any work or with a seasonal laborer about completing his work, with a lazy servant about a big task — pay no attention to any advice they give.
verses.comment: Practical wisdom: seek counsel from the knowledgeable and invested, not from those whose disposition or experience is contrary to your aim; this parallels Proverbs 11:14 and stresses suitability in advisers.

verses.text: But associate with a godly person whom you know to be a keeper of the commandments, who is like-minded with yourself, and who will grieve with you if you fail.
verses.comment: Associate chiefly with godly, like-minded people who share your values and feel your struggles, echoing Psalm 1:1-2 and the importance of righteous companionship.

verses.text: And heed the counsel of your own heart, for no one is more faithful to you than it is.
verses.comment: One’s own conscience and heart—properly formed—are trustworthy guides, akin to the Pauline emphasis on conscience in Romans 2:15.

verses.text: For our own mind sometimes keeps us better informed than seven sentinels sitting high on a watchtower.
verses.comment: Inner discernment is often more accurate than the collective watchfulness of guardians; the value of personal insight is highlighted here.

verses.text: But above all pray to the Most High that he may direct your way in truth.
verses.comment: Despite the value of counsel and self-reflection, the foundational source of guidance is prayer to God—an acknowledgment of divine providence (cf. Proverbs 3:5-6).

verses.text: Discussion is the beginning of every work, and counsel precedes every undertaking.
verses.comment: Careful planning and counsel precede action in ancient wisdom (cf. Proverbs 15:22), reinforcing deliberation before undertaking any endeavor.

verses.text: The mind is the root of all conduct;
verses.comment: All behavior springs from the mind or heart in Hebraic understanding (cf. Proverbs 4:23); intent shapes action.
verses.sectionHeader: The Source and Value of Counsel

verses.text: it sprouts four branches, good and evil, life and death; and it is the tongue that continually rules them.
verses.comment: The mind leads to good or evil, life or death, with the tongue as the instrument of these choices, echoing Proverbs 18:21 on the power of speech.

verses.text: Some people may be clever enough to teach many, and yet be useless to themselves.
verses.comment: Some teach others effectively but fail to apply wisdom to themselves, recalling Paul’s admonition in Romans 2:21 about inconsistency.

verses.text: A skillful speaker may be hated; he will be destitute of all food,
verses.comment: Skill in eloquence alone cannot ensure favor or prosperity, especially if lacking wisdom; people may resent persuasive but empty speech.

verses.text: for the Lord has withheld the gift of charm, since he is lacking in all wisdom.
verses.comment: True wisdom must be accompanied by grace and discernment; lacking these, cleverness may result in rejection or hardship, as wisdom is holistic (cf. James 3:13).

verses.text: If a person is wise to his own advantage, the fruits of his good sense will be praiseworthy.
verses.comment: Wisdom genuinely applied for one’s well-being bears tangible, praiseworthy results, reinforcing the practicality of true understanding.

verses.text: A wise person instructs his own people, and the fruits of his good sense will endure.
verses.comment: A wise leader educates and strengthens his community, and the positive impact of his wisdom outlives him—consistent with Deuteronomy 4:6-8.

verses.text: A wise person will have praise heaped upon him, and all who see him will call him happy.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings public esteem and happiness—echoing Proverbs 3:13-18 on the blessedness of the wise.

verses.text: The days of a person’s life are numbered, but the days of Israel are without number.
verses.comment: Individual lives are finite, but Israel’s legacy and covenantal identity endure—reflecting the enduring people of God (cf. Genesis 17:7).

verses.text: One who is wise among his people will inherit honor, and his name will live forever.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings honor and lasting renown among the people of God, a recurring biblical theme (cf. Psalm 112:6).

verses.text: My child, test yourself while you live; see what is bad for you and do not give in to it.
verses.comment: Self-examination and discipline are vital for a righteous life; discern what leads to sin or harm and avoid it (cf. 2 Corinthians 13:5).

verses.text: For not everything is good for everyone, and no one enjoys everything.
verses.comment: What is suitable or enjoyable varies among individuals, acknowledging the diversity of human temperament; not all pleasures or practices are universal.

verses.text: Do not be greedy for every delicacy, and do not eat without restraint;
verses.comment: Moderation, especially in appetite, is extolled—a frequent theme in wisdom literature (cf. Proverbs 23:20-21); gluttony is warned against.

verses.text: for overeating brings sickness, and gluttony leads to nausea.
verses.comment: Excessive indulgence leads to illness; the strand of wisdom calls for temperance as a protection for health (cf. Philippians 3:19).

verses.text: Many have died of gluttony, but the one who guards against it prolongs his life.
verses.comment: Gluttony has caused both spiritual and physical death, but self-control ensures well-being and longevity, reinforcing the virtue of moderation.
